The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. The most promising approach is to reconstruct quantum mechanics from a set of axioms. The most important of these is the axiom of locality, which is the basis of the Bell theorem. The present paper provides a categorical formulation of locality that is independent of any analytical structure. The formulation is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the origin of parasitism and the evolution of the parasite lifestyle. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some proton channel residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each proton channel subunit. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. This will increase the instability of global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We quantify the magnitude of this instability for the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. They also highlight the importance of considering the impact of climate change on the variability of crop yields in the context of food security. Our results are based on a model that is not calibrated to historical data, so our results should be considered as indicative of the magnitude of the problem rather than precise predictions.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because species-level identification of food plants is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest overlap in food-plant consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that diversity of large herbivores may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also highlight the potential of DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth and composition in large mammal assemblages. These findings have implications for understanding biodiversity in African savanna and beyond.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is a growing problem in the open ocean. However, the magnitude and the fate of this pollution are still open questions. Using data from the Malaspina 2010 circumnavigation, regional surveys, and previously published reports, we show a worldwide distribution of plastic on the surface of the open ocean, mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of each of the five subtropical gyres with comparable density. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface was estimated to be on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The expansion of the motorized fleet could continue in developing countries as they transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental trait that all animals share. However, the mechanisms that allow some animals to produce more offspring than others are not well understood. Here, we use a comparative approach to understand the mechanisms that allow animals to produce more offspring. We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output in mammals and beyond. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. Here we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. VX-765 also reduces truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and preserves tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies. The results also suggest that VX-765 could be a useful tool to study the mechanisms of α-syn toxicity in vitro and in vivo. To control each function, the endothelium processes endlessly arriving requests from multiple sources using separate clusters of cells specialized to detect specific stimuli. A well-developed but poorly understood communication system operates between cells to integrate multiple lines of information and coordinate endothelial responses. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including many auxiliary indicators that are not typically available in public health surveillance systems. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are designed to be useful for a wide range of applications, including epidemiological model development, public health surveillance, and research into the social and behavioral factors that influence the spread of the disease.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health. The role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is poorly understood, and their potential to synthesize natural products has not been investigated. Here, we report the discovery of a diverse array of natural products from anaerobic fungi. We found that anaerobic fungi synthesize a wide range of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and other bioactive compounds. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi are important contributors to the microbiome and could be used as a source of natural products.

Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we use a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The discovered structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The design and fabrication methods can be extended to other fields of materials science and engineering. This work provides a general framework for the design of mechanical structures with desired responses. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein in red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is highly dynamic and is regulated by developmental cues. Here we investigated the role of insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) in the heterochronic regulation of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in human erythroblasts and that its expression is developmentally regulated. IGF2BP1 overexpression in human erythroid cells results in a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This phenotype is associated with reduced BCL11A protein expression and increased fetal hemoglobin levels. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. They also suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. This study also provides a potential explanation for the observation that fetal hemoglobin levels are lower in adults than in fetuses.

Here, we show that the three major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) activate store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote VSMC remodeling. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of plasma membrane ORAI channels. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our data also suggest that LCCBs may be a potential target for the treatment of cardiovascular remodeling. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed forest management on 10 million hectares of federal land. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP’s policy of reducing clearcutting and increasing old-growth habitat improved bird populations. Our results show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral ecosystems but failed to reverse the decline of older forests. The policy also failed to improve populations of older-forest–associated birds. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the importance of monitoring bird populations to evaluate the effectiveness of forest policies. (Show more)

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work demonstrates the potential of computational drug design to accelerate the discovery of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks can be large, making it difficult to train and apply them in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters and with fewer connections between layers. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting network architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results suggest that the proposed network architecture is a promising approach for achieving accurate results with fewer parameters in practice. This approach may be useful in many image-processing problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after the MPT. From 800 to 100 ka, a deep, often overfilled lake occupied the basin, indicating a wetter climate, but these highstands were interrupted by prolonged intervals of extreme drought. Periods of high lake level are observed during times of high eccentricity.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice is associated with reduced sleep duration and quality, reduced daytime alertness, and increased risk of accidents. The mechanisms underlying these effects are not well understood. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-detains the circadian clock, suppresses melatonin, and reduces alertness the following morning. These findings have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. They also highlight the need for further research on the biological effects of electronic devices on sleep. This research is critical to inform public policy and to develop effective interventions to reduce the negative impact of these devices on sleep.

The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in the development of autoimmune diseases has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice induced a spectrum of autoimmunity that was not observed in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deletion affected both central and peripheral tolerance, and the resulting autoimmunity was dependent on the developmental stage of the cells involved. These findings have important implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. In particular, the results suggest that CTLA-4 may be a potential target for the treatment of autoimmune diseases in which the disease is not fatal. This is in contrast to congenital deficiency, which is lethal.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of their extraordinary diversity remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification and traced the evolution of genes enabling specialized plant feeding. Phylogenomic analyses of these datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships and revealed that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. Moreover, corresponding (Jurassic) diversification rate increases suggest that these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species. We propose that these horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoded in plant tissues facilitated the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can also be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines and therapeutics. Our results provide a proof-of-concept for the use of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This work can help to accelerate the development of effective treatments and vaccines against emerging and reemerging infectious diseases. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation

APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform determines AD risk by a factor of 12. APOE is also a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is highly phagocytic. Here, we show that APOE isoform determines the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest solid body in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the brain effects of marijuana are well known, the underlying mechanisms are not. Here, we show that the brain responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are blunted in marijuana abusers, who also show increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that the blunted brain responses to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for comprehending it are among the most mysterious aspects of the mind. Here, we use a cutting-edge machine learning approach to show that the most powerful artificial neural networks can predict neural and behavioral responses to spoken sentences as well as, and often better than, humans. These results suggest that predictive processing plays a fundamental role in how the human brain understands language. They also raise the possibility that advances in artificial intelligence may one day benefit human language processing by mimicking the brain’s neural mechanisms of predictive processing.

Deep learning (DL) has achieved unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is not clear whether this success is due to the inherent properties of DL or to the fact that DL is a black box. We show that the latter is the case. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies that the success of DL is not due to the inherent properties of DL but rather to the fact that DL is a black box.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. A classic experiment published 45 years ago is often cited as evidence for this phenomenon. However, its design flaws have been overlooked. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae that affects the peripheral nerves and the mucosa of the nose. The causative agent of the diffuse form of leprosy, M. lepromatosis, has been shown to be closely related to M. leprae. Here, we present the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis and compare it with that of M. leprae. We find that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to infect the peripheral nervous system, whereas M. leprae has lost this ability. These findings suggest that M. lepromatosis may be a more promising target for developing a vaccine or a treatment for leprosy. Our results also suggest that M. lepromatosis and M. leprae have diverged from their MRCA approximately 14 million years ago. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also intimately related, as revealed by the study of quantum quenches. However, the entanglement dynamics is a highly nonlocal phenomenon, which makes its exact computation a formidable task. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our work opens the door to the study of the entanglement dynamics in a wide class of interacting systems. It also paves the way for the study of the entanglement in the steady state of many-body quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. The only currently available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors, which are associated with safety concerns. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate that is temperature sensitive in vitro and can be grown at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate is highly attenuated in vivo, resulting in reduced weight loss and lung pathology and protection against lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. The vaccine candidate is also highly immunogenic, generating neutralizing antibodies and T-cell responses. The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a mechanistic model to understand the history of a disease. This is especially important in the context of the current COVID-19 pandemic, where models are needed to understand the history of the disease and inform public health decisions. Our model can be used to inform similar studies for COVID-19.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known story, but the evolution of brain neuronal density is not. We present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes and use it to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endothermic lineages. The other two major increases happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in processed foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean that exhibits cultural, linguistic, and genetic traits from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that higher worthwhile ratings are associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. Longitudinally, worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes independently of baseline levels. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. They also suggest that worthwhile ratings may be a useful target for interventions aimed at promoting healthy aging.

The evolution of aquatic lifestyles has been a major driver of mammalian evolution, but the extent to which aquatic lifestyles have driven the evolution of larger body sizes in mammals remains unclear. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and examination of the fossil record to test the hypothesis that aquatic lifestyles are driving the evolution of larger body sizes in mammals. We find that aquatic lifestyles are driving the evolution of larger body sizes in three of four extant aquatic mammal clades. These three independent body size increases are consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium. Our results suggest that the evolution of aquatic lifestyles is a major driver of mammalian evolution.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is known from the Hellenistic period. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread at that site. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides a new perspective on the history of chicken domestication and its spread in the ancient world. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. The role of plant immune peptides in defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for their antifungal activity is not well understood. Here, we report the crystal structure of a unique antifungal NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula. The structure is largely disordered and contains a single four-residue α-helix and one three-residue antiparallel β-sheet stabilized by two disulfide bonds. The peptide exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, and induced reactive oxygen species in germlings of B. cinerea. The antifungal activity of NCR peptides is likely due to their ability to bind to bioactive phosphoinositides in planta, followed by penetration of the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. The structural and functional data presented here provide a structural basis for the antifungal activity of NCR peptides and pave the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This would be a significant advance in the management of plant fungal diseases.

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout human history. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have revealed key evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Y. pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage on grasslands. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular framework for the study of nectar chemistry.

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. In addition, functional variants revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by RNA polymerases. In the laboratory, RNA polymerases are used to synthesize RNA molecules, but they have not been used to replicate RNA. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA molecules. This RNA polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life. (Show more)

Frost damage is a major threat to plant and animal survival, but the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of late-spring frosts are poorly understood. The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green color polymorphism has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution. Our results provide molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of color polymorphism, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. These findings have important implications for understanding the evolution of color polymorphism and the origin of vertebrate color vision.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs) are key regulators of the hypoxic phenotype. Our findings suggest that ALKBH5 may be a potential therapeutic target for breast cancer.

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment from the earliest pocket Bibles to the present day. (Show more)

The chemical properties of atoms are crucial for understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we calculate, as a function of pressure, two central chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, which can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. We find that for most elements, chemical hardness and electronegativity decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemistry of matter under pressure.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can also be applied to other protein molecules, such as vaccines and therapeutics. Our results provide a proof-of-concept for the use of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This work can help to accelerate the development of effective treatments and vaccines against emerging and reemerging infectious diseases. Agricultural production is a key driver of the global economy, and the ability to monitor crop status in space and time is critical to manage production. Current systems rely on satellite imagery, crop models, and meteorological data, but have underutilized legacy sources of information such as crop expert surveys. We show that these surveys, despite their subjective and categorical nature, capture the complexities of assessing the “status” of a crop better than any model or satellite retrieval. We propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on crop expert assessments, and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the Crop Condition Index can be used to provide early warnings of crop production anomalies, and can be used to trigger early action to mitigate the impact of crop failures. This can be particularly important in developing countries where the impact of crop failures can be devastating.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during normal, spontaneous activity. We show that these changes in neuronal excitability can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. Our results suggest that soil respiration may be more responsive to warming in colder climates compared with warmer regions. This may have important implications for the global carbon cycle.

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a powerful tool for reconstructing the evolutionary history of eukaryotic organisms. However, the evolutionary trajectories of plastid genomes are often obscured by the presence of functional genes. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolutionary trajectories of plastid genomes are shaped by the interplay between macroevolutionary events and microevolutionary processes. This model can be used to infer the evolutionary history of organisms from their molecular evolution. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water availability in South Africa. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in South Africa to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for water resource managers and policy makers in South Africa and other regions that are vulnerable to climate change. It also highlights the importance of using high-resolution climate models to assess the impact of climate change. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized condensed matter physics. The first test explosion of a nuclear bomb, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, resulted in the fusion of surrounding sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines into a glassy material known as “trinitite.” Here, we report the discovery, in a sample of red trinitite, of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. It represents the oldest extant anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history. Like the naturally formed quasicrystals found in the Khatyrka meteorite and experimental shock syntheses of quasicrystals, the anthropogenic quasicrystals in red trinitite demonstrate that transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions are suitable for the synthesis of quasicrystals and for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems. We also show that the discovery of the anthropogenic quasicrystal in red trinitite is a serendipitous example of the “right place, right time”

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the presence of which is unique to (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster proteins, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. These results indicate that Ycf54 is a cyclase subunit in oxygenic phototrophs, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages ameliorated EAE severity. ASK1 in astrocytes also contributes to neuroinflammation, and ASK1 deficiency in astrocytes ameliorated the later-stage neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes play distinct roles in neuroinflammation, and ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings also suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes may be a promising therapeutic target for later-stage neuroinflammation. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the roles of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and suggests a potential therapeutic strategy for MS. The 2012–2014 California drought is the driest period in the instrumental record and is the most extreme drought on record. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to anthropogenic warming. The probability that precipitation deficits are also warm is increasing, and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought is increasing. These findings suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions that have created acute human and ecosystem impacts in California. The results also suggest that the probability of drought will continue to increase in a warmer world.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad phenotypic spectrum. The etiology of ASD is so complicated that it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core ASD symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for ASD-risk genes. This study provides a framework for identifying the causal paths that lead to the core ASD symptoms. It also provides a potential target for the development of behavioral therapies for ASD. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results offer the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but they also serve to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” The results also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, which is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and loss-of-function mutations in ORAI1 that result in hematological abnormalities and a range of other clinical features. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also provides a useful resource for the study of CRAC channel function. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of disease pathology. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of the cell membrane, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a model for studying the mechanisms underlying the spread of other disease-causing proteins. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the mechanisms by which viruses spill over from bats to other animals and humans are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, named MTX, selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Cancer cells have a unique metabolic profile, including increased demand for one-carbon units. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both SHMT1 and SHMT2, and have shown that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 blocks tumor growth in a colon cancer xenograft model. We have also shown that one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and that SHMT inhibition can be overcome by formate. Finally, we have shown that DLBCL cells are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, SHMT inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for DLBCL. These findings provide a rationale for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a cancer treatment. This work also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of one-carbon donors as cancer therapeutic targets.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a number of proteins, including superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and FUS. These proteins form intracellular inclusions that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. We observe that the inclusions contain proteins that are supersaturated even more than the native interaction partners, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a potential mechanism for the formation of inclusion bodies in ALS. It also suggests that the inclusion bodies may be a useful biomarker for the disease. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that these devices will be useful for many applications in quantum information science and fundamental physics. The photonic crystal system is a general platform for many-body physics with neutral atoms and could be used to explore new states of matter. The earliest known angiosperms are aquatic plants that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. The discovery of Montsechia, a plant from the early Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

Parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous human pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 thousand years ago) and show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is dated to ∼12.6 thousand years ago, and that the recombination event that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. They also provide a unique opportunity to study the evolution of human populations in the past. This study is also the first to present ancient viral sequences from skeletal remains.

The rate at which the global mean sea level is rising is one of the most important indicators of climate change. This study provides a 25-y time series of the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level. The results show that the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2, which is significantly higher than the previously reported rate of 0.12 ± 0.05 mm/y2. The results also show that the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level is significantly higher than the previously reported rate of 0.34 ± 0.17 mm/y2. The results imply that the global mean sea level could rise 65 ± 12 cm by 2100 compared with 2005, which is roughly in agreement with the IPCC 5th Assessment Report (AR5) model projections. Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in America, but that the increase has been slower for the elderly than for midlife Americans. We also show that the increase in pain has been steeper for those with less education than for those with a bachelor’s degree. This suggests that the erosion of working-class life in America is having a negative impact on health.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme active sites is critical for understanding the mechanisms of catalysis. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach is able to provide atomic-resolution characterization of the active site, including the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains as well as the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site. The detailed picture of structure and reactivity that emerges from this work highlights the fate of the L-serine hydroxyl leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that has caused a large number of human fatalities. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a nucleotide analog that inhibits viral RNA synthesis, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Prophylactic treatment with remdesivir completely prevented the development of clinical disease, and therapeutic treatment significantly reduced the severity of clinical signs, virus replication, and lung lesions. These results support the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses. This study also highlights the importance of nonhuman primate models for the study of emerging respiratory diseases. The data presented here may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri through the strategic delivery of a single glycan. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which in turn modulates the conditions in which it lives. We propose that this strategy is used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis and the potential for glycans to be used as a means of controlling microbial activity. (Show more)

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, with disproportionate impact on students of color and students with disabilities. This study tests whether teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. In three districts, teachers were randomized to a brief, online intervention designed to encourage an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. Evaluated at five middle schools, this intervention halved year-long suspension rates from 9.6% to 4.8%. It also bolstered respect the most at-risk students, previously suspended students, perceived from teachers. Teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions and, moreover, can be changed through scalable intervention. This study has important implications for the future of US schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, precleaved MERS viruses used receptor-proximal, cell-surface proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry, whereas uncleaved MERS viruses trafficked past these cell-surface proteases and into endosomes.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the world’s population are a key lever for reducing environmental impacts. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. This paper reports on a large-scale field experiment that attempted to nudge people to choose more plant-based meals in a university cafeteria. The results provide robust evidence that increasing the proportion of plant-based meals offered in a year-long field experiment led to a proportional increase in plant-based meal sales of 78.8%. These results provide a strong case for further research and development of interventions to increase the proportion of plant-based meals offered in the catering sector. Such interventions could have a major impact on the environment and population health.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a major step forward in understanding the cell surface proteome and glycoproteome in normal and cancer cells. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, there is little evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or electoral outcomes. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is unlikely to have a significant impact on the 2020 presidential election. However, our results also suggest that vote-by-mail may increase overall turnout rates, which could be important in a pandemic. Our results also suggest that vote-by-mail may increase turnout among younger and less educated voters, which could be important in a post–Trump electorate. Finally, our results suggest that vote-by-mail may increase turnout among voters who are more likely to be Democrats, which could be important in a post–Trump electorate.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to millions of deaths worldwide. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune system, and it is possible that the accessory proteins encoded by the SARS-CoV-2 genome may contribute to this evasion. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may contribute to immune evasion. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats and that this process is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular explanation for the pathophysiology of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 agonists may be useful in the treatment of cerebral edema. This study may also provide a molecular basis for the development of new therapies for cerebral edema. The era of big data has led to a proliferation of statistical methods for data analysis. These methods are often designed to find the strongest associations in a dataset. But the fact that we are searching for the strongest associations means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We describe some recent developments in selective inference that allow us to set this higher bar in a principled way. We illustrate the use of these methods in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. We show that zebrafish augmentor ligands play an important role in pigment development. Deficiency in augmentor ligands results in strong impairment in iridophore patterning of embryonic and adult zebrafish that is phenocopied in zebrafish deficient in Ltk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. Our findings provide insights into the physiological function of Alk and Ltk and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. They also suggest that augmentor ligands may be important targets for cancer therapy.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is associated with insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in regulating insulin sensitivity has been well established, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, which was associated with decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes and down-regulation of transcription factor Pax6. These findings revealed a function of STING in β-cell function and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus using in vitro experiments. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also showed that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerotic lesions are highly vascularized and highly proliferative. The vascular environment plays a critical role in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. These findings may lead to the development of a novel therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis.
