Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States. This increase has led to substantial economic and ecological costs. Although climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-started wildfires relative to lightning-started wildfires. Our results highlight the importance of reducing fire risk from human-started wildfires and the need for increased management efforts in regions where human-started wildfires are dominant.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical changes in neighborhoods over time and to study the spatial dynamics of urban change. Our results also have implications for urban planning and policy. For example, our results suggest that policymakers should focus on improving the physical appearances of neighborhoods with college-educated residents and that policymakers should encourage the development of physically attractive neighborhoods near the central business districts. Natural repellents are plant-derived compounds that protect plants from herbivory. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated that dTRPγ ion channel in Drosophila melanogaster mediates avoidance behavior to natural repellents. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. The findings may also be useful for the development of new natural products for human use. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with fetal abnormalities and neurological complications, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including global warming and ocean acidification. In addition, mass bleaching events are pushing coral reefs to the brink of collapse. We show that altered nutrient cycling during heat stress is a primary driver of the functional breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Heat stress increased the metabolic energy demand of the coral host, which was compensated by the catabolic degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promoted the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Energy limitation and altered symbiotic nutrient cycling are thus key factors in the early heat stress response, directly contributing to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In the absence of tumorigenesis, the epithelium maintains tight barrier function and mounts immune responses. Here, we show that tumorigenesis leads to the activation of a JNK-dependent feedback loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. We identify a mechanism by which the microbiome can trigger tumor growth and highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for developing strategies to control tumorigenesis. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings may also have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in other diseases.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Although the majority of breast cancers are hormone receptor–positive, a small percentage of patients develop resistance to endocrine therapy, which is the standard of care. In addition, a small percentage of breast cancers are triple-negative, which also is associated with resistance to endocrine therapy. In this study, we show that the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in a small percentage of breast cancers and is associated with resistance to chemotherapy. We also show that targeting ROR1 with an antibody may improve the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may be a promising strategy for improving the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries that reveals the spatial distribution of this important resource. We find that freshwater fisheries are concentrated in regions with high human population density and low-cost protein availability, and that they are particularly important for the nutrition and livelihoods of the poor. Our analysis also reveals that many river basins are already degraded by other stressors, and that intensive fishing in these regions may undermine efforts to protect biodiversity. Our data can be used to inform the design of more effective conservation and management strategies for inland fisheries. This will be particularly important as the global population continues to grow and demand for freshwater resources increases.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In mammals, however, the CNS is incapable of regenerating after injury, and the regeneration capacity of the PNS is limited. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the C. elegans nervous system that is independent of the MAPK signaling cascade. This DLK-independent regeneration is triggered by sensory activity and is reminiscent of a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings suggest that DLK-independent regeneration is a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, the similarities between DLK-independent regeneration and lesion conditioning suggest that conditioning on sensory activity may be a general mechanism for enhancing regeneration in the adult nervous system. These findings may lead to new strategies for enhancing the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity in eukaryotes. In yeast, hotspots of recombination are largely defined by the binding sites of a single protein, zinc finger protein 9. In plants, the pattern of recombination is less well understood. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination sites in a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination hotspots are interspersed among cold regions of low recombination, and that the distribution of recombination sites is similar to that observed in yeast and mice. These results suggest that recombination patterns in plants may be more similar to those in yeast than previously thought. This is important because yeast is a model organism for studying the molecular mechanisms of recombination.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of distributed neuronal populations. The identification of these networks is a major challenge in the field of functional neuroimaging. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early PD patients, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results illustrate the potential of metabolic imaging to provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is a well-known mechanism for regulating mRNA stability and translation. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes, which we call the 5′ NAD+ cap. We show that this cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. The 5′ NAD+ cap is not found on pre-mRNAs, suggesting that it is produced cotranscriptionally. We propose that the 5′ NAD+ cap could regulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subsets of mRNAs. This discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes may have implications for understanding the regulation of gene expression.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We examined whether epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci are associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-me differences at certain loci associated with glycemia persist for several years during the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These findings may help to explain the mechanisms of metabolic memory and may provide a basis for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diabetes.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that is associated with a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence.

The production of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit is essential for fruit aroma and flavor. However, the biosynthetic pathways of these compounds are not known. Using an introgression population derived from the green-fruited species Solanum pennellii, we identified a locus essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. Silencing of the underlying gene in transgenic plants abolished production of aliphatic and aromatic nitrogenous volatiles in ripe fruit, and metabolomic analysis of these fruit revealed the accumulation of 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid, a known conjugate of cysteine and 3-methylbutanal. This pathway is unique to tomato and provides a major step forward in understanding and ultimately improving tomato flavor quality. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. They also highlight the need to consider the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming in the design of effective conservation and restoration strategies.

We found that grid cells, which are thought to represent the spatial layout of the environment, are anatomically segregated from other cell types, while border, head-direction, and object-vector cells tend to intermingle. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes and environmental cues. Dodder is a rootless parasitic plant that is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. We show that the flowering of the host is required for the flowering of the dodder. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We demonstrate that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they “click.” But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Silicon (Si) is an essential micronutrient for plants, but its function in plant physiology has been debated. Although Si has been shown to enhance plant resistance against abiotic stresses, the role of Si in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been well documented. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder in wild-type plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of jasmonate biosynthesis and perception genes. This interaction between Si and jasmonates is likely mediated by jasmonates, as Si pretreatment of plants with jasmonate biosynthesis and perception gene RNAi silenced plants did not enhance resistance against the rice leaffolder. These results suggest that Si may enhance plant resistance against insect herbivores by priming jasmonate-mediated defense responses. This study provides a mechanism for Si-enhanced resistance against insect herbivores and may help to explain the beneficial effects of Si on plant growth and development. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an important enzyme in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it modulates the lipidome of macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism and of the macrophage lipidome.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by intrinsic plasticity that downregulates neuronal firing rates. We show that this adaptive change in excitability can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver siRNAs across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures determine their ability to deliver siRNAs across the cell wall. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a delivery platform for biomolecules to plants.

Eutrophication is a major threat to aquatic ecosystems worldwide, driven largely by nonpoint nutrient loading from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. We found that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan accounted for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries exhibited nutrient loads that were high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies. Expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This would be a major step toward protecting the health of large water bodies and the services they provide to society.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the rare combination of initial conditions that led to the observed universe is contrasted with the vast majority of possible initial conditions. Our results suggest that the same mechanism may be at work in the design of complex chemical systems.

NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) are a class of autoimmune encephalitis that can cause seizures and paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. However, the mechanisms underlying these paroxysms are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs can change the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and render cortical microcircuits susceptible to overt paroxysms. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs and may help explain the diversity of clinical symptoms observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that NMDAR-Abs may be a useful model for studying the mechanisms underlying paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This may lead to the development of new therapies for patients with these conditions. (Show more)

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system, but the history of the Earth system is poorly understood. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was associated with an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and widespread seafloor anoxia. Earth system modeling indicates that the event was associated with enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes. These results provide insights into the history of abrupt climate change and the Earth system. They also provide a potential mechanism for the origin of the Phanerozoic greenhouse climate state. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the history of the Earth system.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced tropical deforestation in Indonesia by 33%. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Our findings also highlight the importance of monitoring and enforcement of certification requirements. The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. Vertebrates with a single sex determination locus have two sexes, while those with multiple sex determination alleles have more than two sexes. In species with polygenic sex determination, the number of sexes is determined by the number of alleles segregating at the sex determination locus. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that the number of sexes is determined by the number of alleles segregating at the sex determination locus, and that the number of sexes can be increased by the acquisition of a new sex determination allele. These results suggest that the number of sexes is a trait that can be increased or decreased by the evolution or introgression of a sex determination allele. This modularity of secondary sexual characteristics provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. The retina is challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids, which are oxidized and degraded by reactive oxygen species and photoproducts of vitamin A aldehyde adducts. We show that intracellular Fe levels promote bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This finding is important because bisretinoids are redox active and have been implicated in the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration. Our results suggest that Fe chelation may be a useful strategy for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. This interpretation is supported by the demonstration that Fe chelation decreased the oxidative/degradation of A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings have important implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (Show more)

Siphonophores are pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentacles to capture prey. They are considered a highly specialized group, with only a few prey types and no predators that feed on more than one prey type. However, we show that siphonophores can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have evolved into specialists on other prey types. Our results suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of hominin research, but the origins of the distinctive morphology of the modern human hand are poorly understood. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand that is absent in early hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has important implications for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human tool use. (Show more)

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. Agricultural intensification is a key strategy to address these crises, but little consideration is given to the role of natural landscapes such as forests in meeting nutrition goals. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake, and that forest fragmentation can increase consumption of these foods and dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of considering the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

Mechanization has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural machinery, allowing for higher output and more food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
